member.name: T:Macro.Common.ExtensionPoint`1
member.summary: Abstract base class for all extension points.
member.typeparam: The interface that extensions are expected to implement.

remarks.para: To define an extension point, create a dedicated subclass of this class, specifying the interface that extensions are expected to implement. The name of the subclass should be chosen with care, as the name effectively acts as a unique identifier which all extensions will reference. Once chosen, the name should not be changed, as doing so will break all existing extensions to this extension point. There is no need to add any methods to the subclass, and it is recommended that the class be left empty, such that it serves as a dedicated factory for creating extensions of this extension point.
The subclass must also be marked with the in order for the framework to discover it at runtime.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.Utilities.CommandLine
member.summary: Parses command line arguments. May be used directly, or may be subclassed and used in conjunction with to have strongly-typed resolution.

remarks.para: Parses an array of command line arguments. Each argument is treated as either a named parameter, a positional parameter, or a switch, depending on its format. Arguments may be quoted to allow spaces - the .NET runtime removes the quotes prior to providing the arguments to application code.

A named parameter has the form /param:value -param:value /param=value -param=value
There must not be a space between the : or = and the value. Named parameters are stored in the property.

A switch has the form /switch[+-] -switch[+-]
The trailing + or - is optional, and if omitted, the boolean state of the switch is simply toggled. Switch states are stored in the property.
A parameter that does not match either the named or switch form is interpreted as a positional parameter. Positional parameters are stored in the property, in the order in which they occur.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.ServiceProviderExtensionPoint
member.summary: Defines an extension point for service providers.

remarks.para: A service provider is a class that knows how to provide a specific set of services to the application. A given service should be provided exclusively by one provider (i.e. no two providers should provide the same service). The application obtains services through the method.

A service provider may be accessed by multiple threads. For reasons of thread-safety, a service provider should return a new instance of the service class for each call to , so that each thread receives its own copy of the service. If the provider returns the same object (singleton), then the service object itself must be thread-safe.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Platform.GetService``1(Macro.Common.Platform.WithServiceDelegate{``0})
member.summary: Obtains an instance of the specified service for use by the application.

remarks.para: Instead of returning the service directly, this overload passes the service to the specified delegate for use. When the delegate returns, this method automatically takes care of determing whether the service implements and calling if it does. The delegate must not cache the returned service because it may be disposed as soon as the delegate returns. For the single-use scenario, this overload is preferred to the other overloads because it automatically manages the lifecycle of the service object.
This method is thread-safe.

member.typeparam: The service to obtain.
member.param: A delegate that will receive the service for one-time use.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.Scripting.ActiveTemplate

remarks.para: An active template is equivalent to a classic ASP page: that is, it is a template that contains snippets of script code that can call back into the context in which the script is being evaluated. Currently only the Jscript language is supported.
Initialize the template context via the constructor. The template can then be evaluated within a given context by calling one of the Evaluate methods.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.Utilities.FileStreamOpener
member.summary: Provides convenient blocking methods for file opening.
member.remarks: The FileStreamOpener class is an abstraction for file opening. It has a built in mechanism to retry opening a file if there is a sharing collision with the file. This should make software opening files to be more resilliant if files are attempted to be opened at the same time.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Utilities.FileStreamOpener.OpenForSoleUpdate(System.String,System.IO.FileMode)
member.summary: Opens a file for update, using specified mode
member.param: File path
Opening mode
member.returns: A with sole write access.

remarks.para: This methods will block indefinitely until the file is opened or exceptions are thrown because file cannot be open using the specified mode. If it cannot be opened due to access permission (eg, it is being locked for update by another process), the method will try again.
Once the file is opened, subsequent attempt to open the file for writing will fail until the returned stream is closed. However, other processes are allowed to open the files for reading.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Utilities.FileStreamOpener.OpenForSoleUpdate(System.String,System.IO.FileMode,System.Int32)
member.summary: Opens a file for update, using specified opening mode and timeout period.
member.param: File path
File opening mode
timeout (in ms)
member.returns: The stream object for the specified file
member.exception: Thrown when the file cannot be opened after the specified timeout
member.remarks:
This methods will block until the specified file is opened or timeout has been reached. If the file cannot be open using the specified mode because it doesn't exist, exceptions may be be thrown depending on the file opening mode. If it cannot be opened due to access permission (eg, it is being locked for update by another process), the method will try again.
Subsequent attempt to open the file for writing will fail until the returned stream is closed. However, other processes are allowed to open the files for reading.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Utilities.FileStreamOpener.OpenForSoleUpdate(System.String,System.IO.FileMode,System.Int32,System.Threading.ManualResetEvent,System.Int32)
member.summary: Opens a file for update, using specified opening mode and waits until timeout expires or a cancelling signal is set.
member.param: File path
File opening mode
timeout (in ms)
Cancelling signal
Minimum delay between retries
member.returns: The stream object for the specified file
member.exception: Thrown when the file cannot be opened after the specified timeout

remarks.para:
This methods will block until the specified file is opened or when timeout has been reached or the cancelling signal is set. If the file cannot be open using the specified mode because it doesn't exist, exceptions may be be thrown depending on the file opening mode. If it cannot be opened due to access permission (eg, it is being locked for update by another process), the method will try again.
The returned stream will have opened with and permissions. Subsequent attempt to open the file for writing will fail until the stream is closed. However, other processes are allowed to open the files for reading.
If cancel signal is set and the file hasn't been opened, null will be returned.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Utilities.FileStreamOpener.OpenForRead(System.String,System.IO.FileMode)
member.summary: Opens a file for reading, using specified opening mode.
member.returns: a with read permission.
member.remarks:
This method will be blocked indefinitely until the file is opened using the specified mode or exceptions are thrown because it doesn't exist. If access permission exceptions occur, the method will try to open the file again.
The file will be opened using and permissions.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Utilities.FileStreamOpener.OpenForRead(System.String,System.IO.FileMode,System.Int32)
member.summary: Opens a file for reading, using specified opening mode and timeout period
member.param: timeout (in ms)
member.remarks: The file will be opened using and permissions. Once the file has been opened, other processes still can open the files for reading.

File opening mode
timeout (in ms)
Cancelling signal
Minimum delay between retries

remarks.para: This methods will block until the specified file is opened or when timeout has been reached or the cancelling signal is set. If the file cannot be open using the specified mode because it doesn't exist, exceptions may be be thrown depending on the file opening mode. If it cannot be opened due to access permission (eg, it is being locked for update by another process), the method will try again.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.Utilities.LargeMemoryStream
member.summary: An implementation of whose backing store is memory but is optimized to store large streams of data in separate, smaller buffers, giving a total capacity of nearly 2^47 bytes.
member.remarks:
This implementation is similar to in that it stores all data in memory. However, stores data in a single byte buffer, and is thus subject to the 2^31-1 maximum array length of the CLR, as well as potential s when allocating many large streams due to the fragmentation of the large object heap.
is optimized for larger streams of data by storing the data in a series of smaller buffers limited to 64KB in size, thus increasing the apparent stream length limit by nearly a factor of 2^16. The smaller buffers are allocated on the small object heap, where fragmentation is less of a concern due to the ability of the garbage collector to perform memory compaction. Furthermore, the first few buffers are of smaller size, trading off some maximum stream length capacity in order to reduce the overhead for small data streams e.g. a stream of 256 bytes will take up only 1KB instead of a full 64KB)

member.name: F:Macro.Common.Utilities.LargeMemoryStream.MaxLength
member.summary: The maximum length of a instance is 2^47-2^18 = 140,737,488,093,184 bytes.
member.remarks: The first 4 blocks have a total capacity of 2^16 bytes. Subsequent blocks have a capacity of 2^16 bytes each. The total number of blocks is limited to 2^31-1.

member.summary: Computes the index and offset within the block for the given stream position.

member.summary: Gets the size in bytes of the specified block.

member.summary: Provides local persistence for application-critical settings.
member.remarks: Usage of this allows for certain application settings to be designated application-critical and stored in a file separate from the standard application configuration file. Application-critical settings are designated by their presence in the critical settings file, and may not be modified through this provider (similar to how application scoped settings may not be modified through the . If a setting is not explicitly defined in the critical settings file, then the setting is treated as a standard application setting and resolved through the application and user configuration files.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.Utilities.CollectionSynchronizeHelper`2
member.summary: Synchronizes the state of one collection based on the state of another collection.

remarks.para: The term "synchronization" here has nothing to do with threads, but refers to updating the elements of one collection based on the elements contained in another collection. The two collections need not have the same element type.

Call the method to update the "destination" collection so that it matches the contents of the "source" collection. The callback will be used to determine if an item in the source collection represents the same item in the destination collection. For items that appear in the source but not the destination, the callback will be called. For items that appear in the destination collection but not the source collection, the callback will be called. For items that appear in both collections, the callback will be called in order to update the element in the destination collection based on the item in the source collection.
There are two ways to use this class. Either instantiate it directly, providing a set of delegates to implement the callbacks, or create a subclass and override the protected callback methods.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.Utilities.StringDiff
member.summary: Computes the difference between two strings.

remarks.para:
The speed and memory requirements are O(n2) for this algorithm, so it should not be used on very long strings.
Adapted from an algorithm presented here in Javascript: http://www.csse.monash.edu.au/~lloyd/tildeAlgDS/Dynamic/Edit/

The and properties return versions of the left and right strings that are as closely aligned as possible on a character by character basis. '-' characters are inserted into both strings at specific points so as to produce the closest possible alignment, such that AlignedLeft.Length == AlignedRight.Length. The property is a string of the same length that contains a '|' character where the aligned strings match and a space where they don't, e.g. DiffMask[i] = (AlignedLeft[i] == AlignedRight[i]) ? '|' : ' '

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Utilities.StringDiff.Compute(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Computes the difference between two strings, and , respectively.
member.param: The left-hand string.
The right-hand string.
Specifies whether or not to ignore character case.
member.returns: A object containing the results.

member.summary: Returns the left string (input into ), but modified to be aligned with the right string.

member.name: P:Macro.Common.Utilities.StringDiff.AlignedRight
member.summary: Returns the right string (input into ), but modified to be aligned with the left string.

member.name: P:Macro.Common.Utilities.StringDiff.DiffMask
member.summary: Returns a diff mask, each character in which indicates whether or not there is a difference at that position between and (space characters indicate no difference, '|' characters indicate a difference).

member.remarks: After calling this method, the should simply exit.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Utilities.IBackgroundTaskContext.Cancel
member.summary: Allows the to inform that it has successfully cancelled, in response to querying the flag, and return the result object to the foreground thread.
member.remarks: After calling this method, the should simply exit.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Utilities.IBackgroundTaskContext.Error(System.Exception)
member.summary: Allows the to inform that it cannot complete due to an exception, and return the exception to the foreground thread.
member.remarks: After calling this method, the should simply exit. It is technically ok for the background method to allow an exception to go unhandled, an the unhandled exception will still be reported to the foreground thread as an error. However, the VS debugger will break in this case, which may not be desirable.

member.summary: Allows the background thread to ask whether cancellation has been requested.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.Utilities.ThreadPoolBase
member.summary: A base class for thread pools that makes no assumptions about how each thread in the thread pool behaves.
member.remarks: It is unlikely you will ever need to derive from this class. In most cases, either the or the will be adequate to suit your needs.

member.summary: The minimum (and also the default) concurrency for the thread pool.

member.summary: The maximum concurrency for the thread pool.

member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: The number of concurrent threads to start.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Utilities.ThreadPoolBase.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor.
member.remarks: The default number of threads in the thread pool is 1.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Utilities.ThreadPoolBase.OnStart
member.summary: Called before the thread pool is started.
member.remarks: Inheritors that override this method must first call the base method and cannot return true if the base method returns false.
member.returns: False if the thread pool is not in the state, and thus cannot be started.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Utilities.ThreadPoolBase.OnStarted
member.summary: Called when the thread pool has started.
member.remarks: Inheritors that override this method must ensure that the base method gets called in order for the thread pool to function correctly.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Utilities.ThreadPoolBase.OnStop(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Called before the thread pool is stopped.
member.remarks: Inheritors that override this method must first call the base method and cannot return true if the base method returns false.
member.returns: False if the thread pool is not in the state, and thus cannot be stopped.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Utilities.ThreadPoolBase.OnStopped
member.summary: Called when the thread pool has stopped.
member.remarks: Inheritors that override this method must ensure that the base method gets called in order for the thread pool to function correctly.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Utilities.ThreadPoolBase.Start
member.summary: Starts the thread pool.
member.remarks: Repeated calls to this method will do nothing, and no exceptions will be thrown.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Utilities.ThreadPoolBase.Stop
member.summary: Stops the thread pool.
member.remarks: Repeated calls to this method will do nothing, and no exceptions will be thrown.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Utilities.ThreadPoolBase.Stop(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Stops the thread pool, indicating whether or not the thread pool should process any remaining items first before stopping (via the parameter ).
member.remarks: Repeated calls to this method will do nothing, and no exceptions will be thrown.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Scripting.IScriptEngine.CreateScript(System.String,System.String[])
member.summary: Asks the script engine to create an instance of a based on the specified string and variable names.
member.remarks: The variableNames array is an array of names of global variables whose values will be provided to the method. Use of this method may offer better performance than calling in the case where the same script is to be run multiple times, as the script engine may be able to pre-compile portions of the script. However, this is entirely dependent upon the implementation of the script engine.
member.param: The script to create.
The names of any global variables in the script that will be provided by the caller.
member.returns: An executable script object that can be run multiple times.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.Utilities.DelayedEventPublisher
member.summary: A utility for delaying or throttling the publication of an event.

remarks.para: This utility is typically used to delay and/or throttle an event that tends to fire many times within a short period of time, triggering numerous UI updates too fast for the user to register, and potentially even impacting on UI responsiveness.

When triggered on inactivity, the timeout period speciifes the time after which, if has not been called, the delayed event will be published. An example of this usage is on property change events to delay notification until the property value has stabilized.

When triggered periodically, the timeout period specifies the minimum interval between publishing consecutive events while is being called. An example of this usage is on a progress provider to throttle notification while still allowing periodic notification.
As this class uses a internally, it must be instantiated from a UI thread; see for more details.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.Utilities.DelayedEventPublisher`1
member.summary: A utility for delaying or throttling the publication of an event.

remarks.para: This utility is typically used to delay and/or throttle an event that tends to fire many times within a short period of time, triggering numerous UI updates too fast for the user to register, and potentially even impacting on UI responsiveness.

When triggered on inactivity, the timeout period speciifes the time after which, if has not been called, the delayed event will be published. An example of this usage is on property change events to delay notification until the property value has stabilized.

When triggered periodically, the timeout period specifies the minimum interval between publishing consecutive events while is being called. An example of this usage is on a progress provider to throttle notification while still allowing periodic notification.
As this class uses a internally, it must be instantiated from a UI thread; see for more details.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.log4net.RollingFileAppender
member.summary: Appender that rolls log files based on size or date or both.

remarks.para: RollingFileAppender can roll log files based on size or date or both depending on the setting of the property. When set to the log file will be rolled once its size exceeds the . When set to the log file will be rolled once the date boundary specified in the property is crossed. When set to the log file will be rolled once the date boundary specified in the property is crossed, but within a date boundary the file will also be rolled once its size exceeds the . When set to the log file will be rolled when the appender is configured. This effectively means that the log file can be rolled once per program execution.

A of few additional optional features have been added:
Attach date pattern for current log file
Backup number increments for newer files
Infinite number of backups by file size

note.para: For large or infinite numbers of backup files a greater than zero is highly recommended, otherwise all the backup files need to be renamed each time a new backup is created.
When Date/Time based rolling is used setting to will reduce the number of file renamings to few or none.
Changing or without clearing the log file directory of backup files will cause unexpected and unwanted side effects.

remarks.para: If Date/Time based rolling is enabled this appender will attempt to roll existing files in the directory without a Date/Time tag based on the last write date of the base log file. The appender only rolls the log file when a message is logged. If Date/Time based rolling is enabled then the appender will not roll the log file at the Date/Time boundary but at the point when the next message is logged after the boundary has been crossed.

The extends the and has the same behavior when opening the log file. The appender will first try to open the file for writing when is called. This will typically be during configuration. If the file cannot be opened for writing the appender will attempt to open the file again each time a message is logged to the appender. If the file cannot be opened for writing when a message is logged then the message will be discarded by this appender.
When rolling a backup file necessitates deleting an older backup file the file to be deleted is moved to a temporary name before being deleted.

note.para: A maximum number of backup files when rolling on date/time boundaries is not supported.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.log4net.FileAppender
member.summary: Appends logging events to a file.

remarks.para: Logging events are sent to the file specified by the property.

The file can be opened in either append or overwrite mode by specifying the property. If the file path is relative it is taken as relative from the application base directory. The file encoding can be specified by setting the property.
The layout's and values will be written each time the file is opened and closed respectively. If the property is then the file may contain multiple copies of the header and footer.

This appender will first try to open the file for writing when is called. This will typically be during configuration. If the file cannot be opened for writing the appender will attempt to open the file again each time a message is logged to the appender. If the file cannot be opened for writing when a message is logged then the message will be discarded by this appender.
The supports pluggable file locking models via the property. The default behavior, implemented by is to use a Mutex to lock the file across processe

member.summary: Does the work of bumping the 'current' file counter higher to the highest count when an incremental file name is seen. member.name: M:Macro.Common.log4net.RollingFileAppender.ComputeCheckPeriod(System.String)
member.summary: Calculates the RollPoint for the datePattern supplied.
member.param: the date pattern to calculate the check period for
member.returns: The RollPoint that is most accurate for the date pattern supplied
member.remarks: Essentially the date pattern is examined to determine what the most suitable roll point is. The roll point chosen is the roll point with the smallest period that can be detected using the date pattern supplied. i.e. if the date pattern only outputs the year, month, day and hour then the smallest roll point that can be detected would be and hourly roll point as minutes could not be detected.

member.summary: Initialize the appender based on the options set

remarks.para: This is part of the delayed object activation scheme. The method must be called on this object after the configuration properties have been set. Until is called this object is in an undefined state and must not be used.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.log4net.RollingFileAppender.RollOverSize
member.summary: Implements file roll base on file size.

remarks.para: If the maximum number of size based backups is reached (curSizeRollBackups == maxSizeRollBackups) then the oldest file is deleted -- its index determined by the sign of countDirection. If countDirection < 0, then files {File.1, ..., File.curSizeRollBackups -1} are renamed to {File.2, ..., File.curSizeRollBackups}. Moreover, File is renamed File.1 and closed.
A new file is created to receive further log output.
If maxSizeRollBackups is equal to zero, then the File is truncated with no backup files created.
If maxSizeRollBackups < 0, then File is renamed if needed and no files are deleted.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.log4net.RollingFileAppender.RollOverRenameFiles(System.String)
member.summary: Implements file roll.
member.param: the base name to rename

remarks.para: If the maximum number of size based backups is reached (curSizeRollBackups == maxSizeRollBackups) then the oldest file is deleted -- its index determined by the sign of countDirection. If countDirection < 0, then files {File.1, ..., File.curSizeRollBackups -1} are renamed to {File.2, ..., File.curSizeRollBackups}.
If maxSizeRollBackups is equal to zero, then the File is truncated with no backup files created.
If maxSizeRollBackups < 0, then File is renamed if needed and no files are deleted.
This is called by to rename the files.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.log4net.RollingFileAppender.NextCheckDate(System.DateTime,Macro.Common.log4net.RollingFileAppender.RollPoint)
member.summary: Get the start time of the next window for the current rollpoint
member.param: the current date
the type of roll point we are working with
member.returns: the start time for the next roll point an interval after the currentDateTime date

remarks.para: Returns the date of the next roll point after the currentDateTime date passed to the method.

The basic strategy is to subtract the time parts that are less significant than the rollpoint from the current time. This should roll the time back to the start of the time window for the current rollpoint. Then we add 1 window worth of time and get the start time of the next window for the rollpoint.

member.name: P:Macro.Common.log4net.RollingFileAppender.MaxSizeRollBackups
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of backup files that are kept before the oldest is erased.
member.value: The maximum number of backup files that are kept before the oldest is erased.

remarks.para: If set to zero, then there will be no backup files and the log file will be truncated when it reaches .
If a negative number is supplied then no deletions will be made. Note that this could result in very slow performance as a large number of files are rolled over unless is used.
The maximum applies to each time based group of files and not the total.

member.name: P:Macro.Common.log4net.RollingFileAppender.MaxFileSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum size that the output file is allowed to reach before being rolled over to backup files.
member.value: The maximum size in bytes that the output file is allowed to reach before being rolled over to backup files.

remarks.para: This property is equivalent to except that it is required for differentiating the setter taking a argument from the setter taking a argument.
The default maximum file size is 10MB (10*1024*1024).

member.name: P:Macro.Common.log4net.RollingFileAppender.MaximumFileSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum size that the output file is allowed to reach before being rolled over to backup files.
member.value: The maximum size that the output file is allowed to reach before being rolled over to backup files.

remarks.para: This property allows you to specify the maximum size with the suffixes "KB", "MB" or "GB" so that the size is interpreted being expressed respectively in kilobytes, megabytes or gigabytes.
For example, the value "10KB" will be interpreted as 10240 bytes.
The default maximum file size is 10MB.
If you have the option to set the maximum file size programmatically consider using the property instead as this allows you to set the size in bytes as a .

member.name: P:Macro.Common.log4net.RollingFileAppender.CountDirection
member.summary: Gets or sets the rolling file count direction.

remarks.para: Indicates if the current file is the lowest numbered file or the highest numbered file.
By default newer files have lower numbers ( < 0), i.e. log.1 is most recent, log.5 is the 5th backup, etc...
>= 0 does the opposite i.e. log.1 is the first backup made, log.5 is the 5th backup made, etc. For infinite backups use >= 0 to reduce rollover costs.
The default file count direction is -1.

member.name: P:Macro.Common.log4net.RollingFileAppender.RollingStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the rolling style.

remarks.para: The default rolling style is .
When set to this appender's property is set to false, otherwise the appender would append to a single file rather than rolling the file each time it is opened.

member.name: P:Macro.Common.log4net.RollingFileAppender.PreserveLogFileNameExtension
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to preserve the file name extension when rolling.
member.value: true if the file name extension should be preserved.

remarks.para: By default file.log is rolled to file.log.yyyy-MM-dd or file.log.curSizeRollBackup. However, under Windows the new file name will loose any program associations as the extension is changed. Optionally file.log can be renamed to file.yyyy-MM-dd.log or file.curSizeRollBackup.log to maintain any program associations.

member.name: P:Macro.Common.log4net.RollingFileAppender.StaticLogFileName
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to always log to the same file.
member.value: true if always should be logged to the same file, otherwise false.

remarks.para: By default file.log is always the current file. Optionally file.log.yyyy-mm-dd for current formatted datePattern can by the currently logging file (or file.log.curSizeRollBackup or even file.log.yyyy-mm-dd.curSizeRollBackup).
This will make time based rollovers with a large number of backups much faster as the appender it won't have to rename all the backups!

member.name: T:Macro.Common.Utilities.CloneableAttribute
member.summary: Decorates a class as being cloneable.
member.remarks:
When decorated with this attribute, a class must:
Have a default constructor (can be private, protected or public) with an optional -decorated method.
must be true, or an exception will be thrown.
Have a cloning constructor, which has the following signature:
- ClassType(ClassType source, ICloningContext context)
The cloning constructor should have protected or private access and must call the base class' cloning constructor if one exists, or none of the base classes with cloning constructors will be cloned correctly.

member.name: F:Macro.Common.Utilities.CloneableAttribute.UseDefaultConstructor
member.summary: Specifies that the class' default constructor should be used when cloning.

member.remarks: Use of this constructor implies that the class being cloned has a cloning constructor. See for more details.

member.summary: Constructor.
member.remarks: See for more details.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.Utilities.CloneInitializeAttribute
member.summary: Decorates the clone-initialization method of a cloneable class; the method will only be called when is true, otherwise a cloning constructor must exist.

remarks.para: The clone-initalization method must have the same signature as the cloning constructor, with a void return type. See for more details on the cloning constructor's signature.
The method should have private access.
The clone-initialization method is called for each class in the hierarchy beginning with the lowest level cloneable class, and ending with the highest.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.Utilities.OnCloneCompleteAttribute
member.summary: Decorates the clone-complete method of a cloneable class; the method will be called after construction (or initialization) for each cloneable class in the hierarchy.

remarks.para: The clone-complete method must have a void signature (no argument, no return value). The method should have private access.
the clone-complete method is called for each class in the hierarchy beginning with the lowest level cloneable class, and ending with the highest.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.Actions.XmlActionCompiler`2
member.summary: Compiler for compiling a set of actions to execute from an XML file.

remarks.para: The can be used to compile a set of actions to perform from XML. The method can be called to create the set of actions to be performed. These actions can then be executed based on input data.

Actions are defined by the extension point. The compiler does not contain any predefined actions. The compiler makes no assumptions about the attributes of the for the action. Any attributes can be defined for the action and are interpreted by the operation defined for the action type.

member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Actions.XmlActionCompiler`2.Compile(System.Xml.XmlElement,`1,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Compile a set of actions to perform.

remarks.para: This method will parse the child s of . Based on the name of the element, the the compiler will look for an extension that handles the element type. A list is constructed of all actions to perform, and a class implementing the interface is returned which can be called to exectute the actions based on input data.

member.param: The input XML containg actions to perform.
Check the schema when compiling.
member.returns: A class instance that implements the interface.

member.summary: Runs the processor.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Shreds.QueueProcessor.RequestStop
member.summary: Requests the task to exit gracefully.
member.remarks: This method will be called on a thread other than the thread on which the task is executing. This method should return quickly - it should not block. A typical implementation simply sets a flag that causes the method to terminate. must be implemented in such a way as to heed a request to stop within a timely manner.

member.summary: Implements the main logic of the processor.
member.remarks: Implementation is expected to run indefinitely but must poll the property and exit in a timely manner when true.

member.remarks: The thread in the corresponding to this QueueProcessor is given its Name.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.Shreds.QueueProcessor`1
member.summary: Abstract base class for queue processor classes.

remarks.para: This class implements the logic to process a queue of items. It polls the queue for a batch of items to process, processes those items, and then polls the queue again. If the queue is empty, it sleeps for a preset amount of time.
All threading is handled externally by .

member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: Max number of items to pull off queue for processing.

member.summary: Gets the next batch of items from the queue.

member.name: M:Macro.Common.Shreds.QueueProcessor`1.ClaimItem(`0)
member.summary: Claims the item for processing.
member.remarks: This method is provided to enable the possibility of clustered queue processing - that is, having multiple processes operate on the same queue concurrently. In this case, a process needs to claim a given item to ensure that no other process operates on it. The default implementation of this method does nothing and returns true.

member.summary: Implements the main logic of the processor.

member.name: T:Macro.Common.AttributeExtensionFilter
member.summary: Implements an extension filter that performs matching on attributes.
member.remarks: For each attribute that is supplied to the constructor of this filter, the filter will check if the extension is marked with at least one matching attribute. A matching attribute is an attribute for which the method returns true. This allows for quite sophisticated matching capabilities, as the attribute itself decides what constitutes a match.
